msDesc.head: Charters, Letters, Bulls, Liturgical Texts, Poetry in Latin, Anglo-Norman and Old French

summary.seg: Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 405 (hereafter CCCC MS 405) is a complex composite manuscript formed from several originally separate booklets, some of which exhibit signs of originating from the same source, or having been brought together relatively soon after their creation, due to the appearance of annotations by the same scribe in more than one part. With the exception of the parchment and paper endleaves (ff. a, i, ii, b), the majority of the present codex was owned by (and probably brought together by) the community of the Knights Hospitaller of St John of Jerusalem at Waterford in Ireland by the middle of the fourteenth century at the latest.

The medieval sections of the manuscript date from the 13th and 14th centuries and contain a wide variety of textual material, including liturgical forms, charters and legal customs, calendars, poems, and treatises on virtue and vice. The manuscript contains texts in both Latin and variants of medieval French, with linguistic divisions largely conforming to the genres of the texts, i.e., legal and liturgical material in Latin, and poems in medieval French.

Although CCCC MS 405 is a composite volume - and one that has suffered evident losses, particularly in the latter part of the codex - it is apparent that at least two scribes worked on more than one part of the manuscript. CCCC MS 405 'Scribe 1' writes a heavy textualis with long horizontal serifs and wedges on his ascenders and seems to have been responsible for ff. 3v-5v, 43r-92r, 127r-230v. CCCC MS 405 'Scribe 2' writes a neat late protogothic / early textualis and was responsible for ff. 8v-10r, 125r-127r and ff. 231r-245r. This detail about the recurring scribes does not seem to have been discussed in scholarship before, and would benefit from further research in order to better understand the complex construction and use of this volume.

CCCC MS 405 became part of the Parker Library collection through the bequest of Archbishop Matthew Parker, a former Master of the College who amassed a large collection of manuscripts in the latter years of his life. MS 405 bears evidence of the interest of Parker and his circle in the book: folio ii recto contains a selective list of the contents of the volume on an inserted paper leaf in a 16th-century hand found in several other Parker Library manuscripts with no prior shared provenance, indicating that the list was added by Parker or one of his circle while making a study of the manuscripts collected for Parker's research on the history of Christianity and ecclesiastical practices in the British Isles.

Dr Sarah Gilbert
Project Cataloguer for the Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries Project
Cambridge University Library

supportDesc.support: All medieval leaves parchment. One 16th century parchment endleaf (f. i), one 16th century paper endleaf (f. ii), and two modern paper endleaves (ff. a and b), one at each end of the volume.

foliation.p: Foliation sequence added in the second half of the 20th century or the first quarter of the 21st century.

note.p: Foliated in pencil in the upper outer corner of each recto. The modern paper endleaves at each end of the volume are foliated as folios 'a' and 'b', the first parchment endleaf is foliated as folio 'i', the second parchment endleaf is foliated as folio 'ii' and the main Hindu-Arabic numeral sequence runs from ff. 1-251.

foliation.p: Pagination sequence added in the 16th century, before 1575. This pagination sequence is no longer in use.
Pages 1-501 (for ff. i, 1-250). Folios ii and 251 unpaginated in this sequence.

note.p: Paginated in orange crayon in Hindu-Arabic numerals in the upper outer corner of each recto; the orange crayon pagination is a typical sign of the use of the book by Archbishop Matthew Parker and his circle.

collation.p:
A composite manuscript arranged as follows:
One modern paper endleaf (f. a) +
One early 16th century parchment endleaf (f. i) |
One 16th century paper endleaf (f. ii) |
Quire 110 (ff. 1-10) |
Quire 26 (ff. 11-16) |
Quire 312 (ff. 17-28)
Quire 412+2 (ff. 29-42; 2 leaves added after the 7th leaf)
Quires 5-1012 (ff. 43-114)
Quire 118+1+1 (ff. 115-124; two singletons pasted together and then a quire of 8 leaves) |
Quire 1210 (ff. 125-134)
Quires 13-2012 (ff. 135-230) |
Quires 21-228 (ff. 231-246) |
Quire 23five (ff. 247-251; original quire structure undetermined, original first leaf certainly gone, five leaves remain) +
One modern paper endleaf (f. b)

p.formula: One modern paper endleaf + one medieval parchment endleaf | one 16th century paper endleaf | 110 | 26 | 312 410+2 (2 leaves added after the 7th leaf) 5-1012 118+1+1 | 1210 13-2012 | 21-228 | 23five + one modern paper endleaf

signatures.p: No leaf signatures common to the entire volume.

Quire signatures in pencil in Hindu-Arabic numerals in the lower outer corner of the first recto of each quire. Most quires also have late medieval signatures written in faint grey-brown ?crayon in Roman numerals in the lower outer corner of the first recto of each quire, and it is possible more of this sequence has been lost to abrasion and/or trimming. The medieval signature sequence is as follows:
Quire 4: iiii
Quire 5: u
Quire 6: ui
Quire 7 (faint): uii
Quire 8: uiii
Quire 9: ix
Quire 10: x
Quire 11 (partially trimmed away): xi
Quire 12: xii
Quire 13: xiii
Quire 15: xv
Quire 16: xvi
Quire 17: xvii
Quire 18: xviii
Quire 19: xix
Quire 20: xx

catchwords.seg: No catchwords common to the entire volume.

binding.p: Rebound by John P. Gray in 1954. Fully bound in light brown leather over wood boards. Five raised bands on spine (not photographed), each decorated with a single fillet at their upper and lower perimeter that extends over the joints and taper toward each other to a point finished with a dot on the front and rear covers. Approximate binding dimensions (L x W x H): 235 x 160 x 50 mm.

Paper pastedowns pasted over the turn ins, both blank. One paper flyleaf at each end of the volume, ff. a and b. A note about the 1954 rebinding is written in ink on f. a recto: 'Rebound by John P. Gray of Green St. (Pilgrim Trust grant) 22. xii . 1954' and signed 'J.P.T.B.', i.e. John Patrick Tuer Bury (1908-1987), historian and fellow of Corpus Christi College. Folio a recto also bears a College stamp in black ink ('Corpus Christi College Cambridge') and the M. R. James Catalogue number for volume written in blank ink, ('MS 405').

provenance.p: Owned by Matthew Parker (1504-1575) Parker, Matthew, 1504-1575, archbishop of Canterbury. A pagination sequence in the orange-red crayon characteristic of Parker and his circle is present throughout the volume (apart from f. ii, a leaf added by Parker or one of his circle) indicating that all Parts of the present codex were together by the time it was studied by Parker and his circle.

acquisition.p: Bequeathed to Corpus Christi College Cambridge in the will drawn up by Matthew Parker (1504-1575) Parker, Matthew, 1504-1575 in 1574. Parker died in 1575, and his bequest was transferred to Corpus Christi College over several years following his death.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on M.R. James, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Manuscripts in the Library of Corpus Christi College, Cambridge, 2 vols (Cambridge, 1912), no. 405; N. Wilkins, Catalogue des manuscrits francÌ§ais de la BibliotheÌque Parker (Parker Library), Corpus Christi College, Cambridge (Cambridge, 1993). Images and a description of the manuscript are also available on the Parker Library website: Corpus Christi College, MS 405.

availability.p: Visitors to Corpus Christi College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Parker Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Parker Library: Information for Readers.

custodialHist.custEvent: Catalogued as item 70 in Thomas James' Ecloga Oxonio-Catabrigiensis, printed in London in 1600.

Catalogued as item G.4 in William Stanley's Catalogus librorum manuscriptorum in Bibliotheca Collegiis Corporis Christi in Cantabrigia: Quos legauit Matthaeus Parkerus Archiepiscopus Cantuariensis printed in London in 1722.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 405, folio i

note.p: Fragment of a legal document, now cut down from its original size and probably used as a pastedown in a former binding.

Partial notarial mark (notary signature) present in the upper outer corner of the leaf. The notarial mark is incomplete but appears to be the mark of John Stoberd, who acted as notary for Richard Fox Fox, Richard, 1447 or 1448-1528 (b. 1447 or 1448, d. 1528), founder of Corpus Christi College, Oxford and at various times Bishop of Exeter, Bath and Wells, Durham, and Winchester. John Stoberd acted as notary for Fox, when Fox admitted Thomas Cisson as Master of Baliol College, Oxford in 1511. The document admitting Cisson to the position of Master of Bailiol is now Oxford, Balliol College, Archives, MS D.3.3 and Stoberd's notarial mark can be seen in the lower portion of the document.

The text is badly damaged but mentions an Abbot Richard in connection with the location Chale: this may refer to Richard Kennock who was rector of the parish church of Chale in the Isle of Wight c. 1516.

No quire signatures particular to this Part.

supportDesc.condition: Folio i was originally a much larger document, and appears to have been trimmed for reuse as a pastedown in a former binding. Much of the text has been lost to trimming.

p.seg: Ruled in single-column format, in leadpoint, frame only. The leaf has been significantly trimmed for reuse as binding waste and the original dimensions and number of lines cannot be determined.

handNote.p: Written in an early 16th century secretary hand by public notary John StoberdJohn Stoberd. Single-compartment minuscule a. Looped ascenders on most bs and ls. Minuscule h is tilted, has a looped ascender, and the 'leg' stroke is elongated, tilted back towards the ascender, and terminates in a flicked foot.

decoNote.p: Portion of a notarial mark belonging to John Stoberd present in the upper outer corner of f. i verso.

binding.p: Folio i was probably used as a pastedown in a former binding as there is adhesive residue on f. i recto.

origin.origDate: Probably first quarter of the 16th century.

msItem.title: List of the contents of the volume

note.p:
Full transcription:
Contenta in hoc Libro pag: 502 .
3 . 251. Epistole summorum pontificum ad fratres de hierusalum in hibernia
5 Charta Edwardi
8 Prophetie marlini gallice
12 De sex aetatibus seculi
18 De vita christiana . etc .
23 Kalendarium 35 De festo corporis christi et aliis festis
190 Carta de libertatibus de waterforde
195 Ordinationes in dicta civitate gallice
232 Consuitudinis ferie eiusdem civitat
236 Constitutiones ville de Bristol
239 Carta ville de Drogheda
243 Carta ville de Hauerfforde
245 Annales quidam
255 rithmi gallice de diuersis rebus 463 . De rebus quibusdam theologiis Gallice

This list of the contents of the volume was probably added by Archbishop Matthew Parker or one of his circle as this is one of several manuscripts in the Parker collection, each of differing provenance, but all bearing a list of the contents of the volume in this hand (see for example, Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MSS 105, f. iii verso and 385, f. i verso). The numbers at the start of each lemma refer to the Parkerian pagination sequence added to the volume, but now no longer in use.

signatures.p: No leaf signatures particular to this Part.
No quire signatures particular to this Part.

catchwords.seg: No catchwords particular to this Part.

supportDesc.condition: In fair condition, although the leaf exhibits signs of previous liquid damage, particulary on the verso.

p.seg: Informally written with no ruling visible.

handNote.p: Written in an informal and idiosyncratic secretary hand, perhaps influenced by humanist training in Greek minuscule. Minusucle h is particularly unusual, the ascender frequently does not meet the baseline, and the hook and the minim stroke for the 'leg' of the h frequently drops below the line or joins the next letter in an informal ligature. Minuscule r when written separately from its proximate letters resembles a minuscule Greek Î¾ (xi). Majuscule C resembles a circle divided into quarters with the circumference around the upper left quarter erased. This hand belongs to Archbishop Matthew Parker or one of his research circle.

decoNote.p: No significant decoration in this Part.

note.p: The number '405' in pencil (the M. R. James, Catalogue number for this volume) on folio ii recto.
The former classmark 'G.4' in ink (the William Stanley Catalogus number for this volume) on folio ii recto.

origin.p: Date and place of production assigned based on palaeographical features, and similarity to other selective lists of the contents of volumes collected by Archbishop Matthew Parker and annotated by Parker and his circle.

msItem.title: List of Kings of England from Aethelwulf of Wessex to Edward II
msItem.incipit: 6v Ly Reys Athewlter regna .xviij. aunz
msItem.explicit: 7r Puis Edward soun fuiz qe auoit Regne quant ceste date fu fete xviij aunz

note.p: 'Athewlter' probably refers to King Aethelwulf - King Aethelwulf of Wessex reigned for 18 years and was followed by an Aethelbald (or 'Athelbaud' as he is described in this manuscript).

Smallwood, in his discussion of the The Prophecies of the Six Kings to Follow John offered a general description of the Anglo-Norman texts on ff. 3v-10v and suggested that this regnal list must have been copied c. 1325/26, i.e., in the 18th regnal year of the reign of Edward II. Edward II is the final king in the regnal list, and in the list, Edward is said to have reigned for 18 years. King Edward II reigned for 20 years (1307-1327), but a scribe writing in the reign of Edward II would have only been able to state the duration of Edward's reign at the time of writing, e.g., 18 years which places the date of the composition of the regnal list c. 1325/1326.

msItem.title: Amuletic charm incorporating the Letter of Jesus to King Abgar
msItem.incipit: 9v Seynt leon apostoile de Rome escrit ceste lettre e dit ky vnkys le lirra ia cel iour ne estout detur sun enimi
msItem.explicit: 10r in dei nomine securus ambulabit
msItem.finalRubric: 10r Explicit epistola quam dominum nostrum Ihesum Christum manum scriptam misit ad abagarem Regem qui eum videre desiderabit + Ihesus + Nazarenus + Rex + Iudeorum + Miserere mei +

note.p: The opening lines of the text in this manuscript attribute it to a Pope Saint Leo ('Seynt leon apostoile de Rome', but as five Popes with the papal name Leo have been canonised (I, II, III, IV, and IX), it is unclear which Pope Leo is meant in the text). The closing lines of the text however, describe the text as a copy of the letter of Jesus to King Abgar of Edessa. The text is usually descibed in modern scholarship as an apocryphal letter of Jesus to King Abgar.

The text suggests that people suffering from illnesses 'si homme seyt malade' should wear the letter around their neck 'pendet set bref autour sonn cole' in order to achieve relief from their symptoms.

The text contains a formula of address, where a person performing the charm asks for help on behalf of another person, and in this letter, the intended recipient of the benefit of the charm is named in the text as 'William', 'assistunt hinc famulo tuo +Willelmo+ hoc scriptum portanti'; no further information is known about the identity of this William.

p.seg: Folios 1r-3r ruled in ink, frame and lines. Ruled in single-column format, typically 29 lines to the page and written below top line.
Folios 1r-3r ruled in ink, frame and lines. Ruled in single-column format, typically 30 lines to the page and written below top line.

handNote.p: Folios 1r-2v and note in lower margin of f. 9r written in Cursiva Antiquior with some documentary and chancery features. Double-compartment minuscule a. Looped ascender on minuscule d. Ascenders for b, h, l, not always completed with a closed loop, but often terminated in a large hook extending from the tip of a clubbed ascender. Long macron abbreviation strokes. Feet on minims. Strong contrast between heavy ascenders and narrow general text.

Folios 3v-5v written in an informal northern Textualis libraria by CCCC MS 405 'Scribe 1' who also seems to be responsible for the text on ff. 43r-92r and 127r-230v. Double-compartment minuscule a. Feet on minims. Sloping backed d. This scribe uses both deeply forked and long flat horizontal serifs on most ascenders.
Folios 5v-8r and f. 10v written in anglicana. Written in a hand similar to that of the scribe who wrote ff. 1r-2v, but with frequent use of long forked ascenders on b, h, and l.

Folios 8v-10r written in a neat northern Textualis libraria by 'Scribe 2' who also seems to be responsible for ff. 125r-127r and 231r-245r. Double-compartment minuscule a. Feet on minims. Sloping backed d. Ascenders usually terminated in small forked or ~ -shaped serifs. This scribe has a 'neater' aspect than the scribe that copied ff. 3v-5v.

decoNote.p: Unfilled space for a decorative initial 'A' on f. 1r.
Rubrication (red only) and red paraph marks ff. 3v-5v

origin.origDate: Second quarter of the 14th century, perhaps c. 1325/1326.
origin.p: As noted by Smallwood, the regnal list on ff. 6v-7r was probably copied c. 1325/26, since Edward II, the last ruler to be named, is given a regnal duration of 18 years. i.e., in the 18th regnal year of the reign of Edward II.
Place of production assigned based on Irish place names described in the text and the connection of this volume to the Knights Hospitaller community of St John of Jerusalem at Waterford in Ireland.

note.p:
The calendar contains a poem (a line per page) on the Dies egypti, full transcription:
Prima dies mensis et septimus truncat ij ut ensis
Quarta subut mortem prosternit tertia fortem
Primus mandentem dirumpit quarta bibentem
Denus et undenus est mortis uulnere plenus
Tertius occidit et viius ora relidit
Denus pallesit quindenus federa nescit
Tredecimus mactat iuli denus labefereat
Prima necat fortem perdiditque secunda cohortem
Tercia cum dena clamat sis integra uena
Tertius et denus est sicut mors alienus
Scorpius est quintus et tertius est necetinctus
Septimus exsanguis uirosus denus ut angis

p.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame and lines. Typical medieval calendar mise-en-page, typically 33-35 lines to the page and written above top line.

handNote.p: The majority of the calendar is written in a neat protogothic minuscule with soem textualis features. Limited 'biting' of letters. Double-compartment minuscule a. Mix of sloping- and straight-backed d. Minuscule y is usually undotted. Feet on minims and descenders. There are later additions in several hands.

decoNote.p: Sketch of an (untonsured) male head and torso; the man is wearing a robe and holding a book in an outstretched hand on f. 12r
Flourished 'KL' ciphers on each page in red or green, or both colours in combination.

origin.origDate: Probably last quarter of the 12th century or first half of the 13th century.
origin.p: Date of production assigned based on palaeographical features. Place of production assigned based on the significant number of Irish saints commemorated in the calendar.

listBibl.bibl: Partially edited in N. Wilkins, Catalogue des manuscrits francÌ§ais de la BibliotheÌque Parker (Parker Library), Corpus Christi College, Cambridge (Cambridge, 1993), p. 114

collation.p:
There is a significant change of handwriting style and page layout between f. 93r and f. 94v (ff. 93v-94r blank), but the change in hand and mise-en-page occurs because of a change of scribes in the middle of Quire 9, and not because ff. 94-124 derive from an originally separate manuscript source. The quires in Part 5 are arranged as follows:
Quire 312 (ff. 17-28)
Quire 412+2 (ff. 29-42; 2 leaves added after the 7th leaf)
Quires 5-1012 (ff. 43-114)
Quire 118+1+1 (ff. 115-124; two singletons pasted together and then a quire of 8 leaves)

signatures.p: Medieval alphabetical leaf signatures in brown crayon in the lower margins of the rectos in the first half of Quire 7 (ff. 67r-78v) marked with designations a-f . Medieval Roman numeral leaf signatures in brown crayon in the lower margins of the rectos in the first half of Quire 8 (ff. 79r-90v) marked with the designations i-uj.

Quires are numbered in grey-brown crayon in Roman numerals in the lower outer corner of the recto of most quires in this Part as follows: Quire 4 = iiii; Quire 5 = v etc. This signature sequence appears in the volume for the first time in this Part, but continues into other Parts.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords in text-ink in the lower margin of the last verso of Quires 3-9. Some catchwords enclosed in decorative frames, e.g., a detailed fish frame in red ink on f. 54v.

supportDesc.condition: In good condition. Medieval sewn repair on f. 40, thread still present in leaf.

p.seg: Layout for ff. 17r-93r: ruled in leadpoint, frame and lines. Ruled in single-column format, typically 24 lines to the page and written below top line.
Layout for ff. 94v-124v: ruled faintly in leadpoint, frame and lines. Ruled in single-column format, typically 24-27 lines to the page and written below top line.

handNote.p: Folios 17r-35v and 38r-42v written in a somewhat rounded northern textualis libraria. Double-compartment minuscule a. Sloping-backed-d. Caroline-s in initial position at the beginning of clauses, as the terminal form, and for proper nouns, but long-s with small shoulder used in most initial, and all medial positions. Small wedges on ascenders.

Folios 36r-37r written in a narrow northern textualis libraria. Double-compartment minuscule a. Sloping-backed-d. Caroline-s in initial position at the beginning of clauses, as the terminal form, and for proper nouns, but long-s used in most initial, and all medial positions. Dotted-y.

Folios 43r-92r written by CCCC MS 405 'Scribe 1' in a northern textualis libraria, of less rounded aspect than the work by the scribe of ff. 17r-35v and 38r-42v. Lower limb of g barely drops below the base line. Long flat ascenders on ll ligatures. Thick wedges in the upper portion of most of the ascenders of b, h, and l. Small shoulder-bump on long-s. Crossed-z. This scribe also seems to be responsible for ff. 3v-5v and 127r-230v.
Medical recipe on f. 92r written in anglicana. Double-compartment minuscule a. Frequent use of forked ascenders on b, h, and l. Minuscule g resembles the hindu-arabic numeral 8. Dotted y.

Folios 92v-93r written in a northern textualis semi formata. Double-compartment minuscule a. Sloping-backed-d. Wedged ascenders on b, h, and l. Some 'biting' of letter forms. Attempts at diamond-feet on minims.

Folios 94v-124v written in anglicana with some secretary features. Double-compartment a. Forked ascenders on b, h, and l. Caroline s in initial and terminal positions, and long-s sometimes on the line and sometimes below in medial positions.

decoNote.p: Flourished initials in red and blue in various styles, e.g., blue initial with 'labrynthine' florushing in red on f. 25r, puzzle initial on f. 30r.
Plain initials in red or blue in a 'Lombardic' style at the minor divisions of the text.
Rubrication (red only) at the major and minor divisions of the text and for the letters and sigla indicating the speaker of and the progress through the liturgical form.
Marginal doodle (of a flourished letter 'A'?) in red and black in the lower margin of f. 80v

note.p: Marginal 'highlights' in Parkerian red crayon against several passages of text e.g., ff. 28v, 30v etc.

origin.p: Date of production assigned based on palaeographical features and dates referred to in the text. Place of production assigned based on significant number of references to Irish places and persons.

msItem.title: Bull of Pope Boniface VIII confirming the Rule of the Knights Hospitallers by Raymond du Puy
msItem.author: Pope Boniface VIII
msItem.incipit: 125r Bonifacius Episcopus seruus seruorum dei
msItem.explicit: 127r Datum lateran . vii . Idus aprilis pontificatus nostri anno sexto .

note.p: The bull was issued 'vii . Idus aprilis pontificatus nostri anno sexto', i.e., 7 April 1300.

msItem.title: The Anglo-Norman translation of the 'Rule' of the Knights Hospitaller
msItem.author: Raymond du Puy
msItem.incipit:
127r Al tens zezar le premerain
Ke empereur fu romain
E al tens antiochi
Ke fu prince de sus lui
Eu une esueske en la cite
Ke ierusalem est a pele
Par soun dreit mu quant fu nez
Melchiazar fu apelez
Cist fu pro dome de sa lay
Fors tant cum il fist une desray
Quant del sepulcre seint dauid
Besans et uestemens fors rauid
msItem.explicit:
154v Tuz nus eime deu par sa grace
AmeN ameN e deu le fasce
E par sa pite
Nus doint uiure en uerite
Bein uiure e bein murir
Ceo seit deshore nostre desir
E tel seit nostre entente
Ke deu nus otriet la grant rente
La quele ia ne poet descretre
Par len seignement de nostre mestre

note.p: Also in the former Phillipps MS 8336, now London, British Library, MS Add. 46919

The text of the poem (based on the version in London, British Library, MS Add. 46919 is discussed in W.H. Robinson, The Famous Fourteenth Century Composite Volume Containing Eighty separate texts (of which no less than forty-five are unique) including the autograph manuscript of the lyrics of an otherwise unknown early fourteenth century English poet, he earliest manuscript of the first treatise on hunting written by an Englishman, etc (London, 1950).

msItem.title: Poem on the Joys of the Virgin Mary and Litany of Saints
msItem.incipit:
155r Aue seinte marie mere al creatur
Reine des angles plaine de dusur
Aue esteile de meir de grant resplendisur
Eschele de parais saluz de pecheur
Aue seinte marie la uerge al rai iesse
msItem.explicit:
158r E si requer les uirgines e cele duce flurs
Requerez ma dame ke ele ma sait succurs
Gloriuse raine eez de mai merci
Pur amur Ihesu crist ducement vus pri
Qui cum patre et filio uiuit et regnat deus per omnia secula seculorum AmeN

msItem.title: Distichs of Cato translated into Anglo-Norman by Elias of Winchester
msItem.author: Cato, Marcus Porcius
msItem.incipit:
158r-158v Ki uout sauer la faitement
Ke catun a sun fiz aprent
Si en latin nel set entendre
Ici le pot en rumaunz aprendre
Cum helis de guyncestre
Ki deu mette a sa destre
Lat translate si fatemente
Dit catun al cumencemente
Cum ieo ma apacuy mut plusurs
Greuement a folaer es murs
msItem.explicit:
170v Ceo fit la breuent de mun ententement
Ken la raisun ioius deus vers sulement
Kil translata len entent tut autresy
Duz helyes dunt deus ait mercy

note.p: 'Helis de guyncestre' (line 6) is now usually known in Anglophone scholarship as Helis of Winchester or Elias of Winchester.

msItem.title: Sermon on loving and fearing God, and the Last Judgement in verse
Sermon on loving and fearing God, and the Last Judgement in verse
msItem.incipit:
171r Chescun deit estre ame
Par la mesure de sa bounte
Chescun uaut taunt cum il eime
Si cum seint pol uus enseigne
Il dist si il eust chescun ben
Si il ne eust amur ne serreit ren
Kar ne eist home taunt de uirtuz
Si il ne eist amur trescut est uuz
msItem.explicit:
178r Ausi cum par mi ta nus
Lalme od deu nad pour nus
Kar tost aueroit pour parfite
Ki ben pensat de mort subite

msItem.title: Sermon on loving and fearing God, and the Last Judgement in verse
msItem.incipit:
178r Ore escutez del iugement
Dount pour uent ensement
Ceo est a iour de iuise
Kaunt serra estreite iustise
Iur de graunt amerte
Iur de graunt cheitiuete
msItem.explicit:
183v Prium deu omnipotent
Ke cel e tere fist de nent
Ke sa ioie nus otrie
Od lui en la pardurable uie
La nus meine la douce marie . amN

note.p: Treated as two texts (ff. 171r-178r and 178r-183v by M. R. James, and one text (ff. 171r-183v) by Dean and Boulton.

msItem.incipit:
183v-184r Deu omnipotent
Ke al comencement
Creat cel e tere
Nus seit cumfort
E doint deuaunt la mort
Verrai penaunce fere
msItem.explicit:
196v Il est issi escrit
Ke li apostle dist
Ke solum sun poer
Pur deu uoudra suffrir
E peine od li partir
E od li purra regner Aitel regne nus meine
Ke pur nus suffir peine
Iesu le tresduz
Pur le amur de sa amie
La pucele marie
AmeN diez tuz

msItem.title: On the divisions of the world
msItem.author: Perot de Garbelei
msItem.incipit:
196v-197r Un liure de haut eure
Ki descrist et deskeure
Les choses de ceo mund
E les gens ki i sunt
A ie en cunte troue
Meint bon clert ben funde
E de clergi eslit
Ferment preisent ceste liure
E founde de clergie
Ki le lisent ou manie
Kar tute est en latin
Del chef derk en la fin
Plusurs clers dient ben
Ke nul pour nule ren
Taunt ne sauereit de lettre .
Ne purreit mie mettre
En romance ne rimer
Tant ne sauereit limer
Pur ceo sen est par fei
Perot de garbelei
Entremis pur auer
Le gre e le uoler
E de clers e de lais
Kar requide ke unke mes
Ne fu fet tel romanz
msItem.explicit:
212r Ore awm acumplies
Del mund les treis parties
Dist vus auum leuement
Tut le establement
Del mund e queus i est
Grant preu e grant conquest
Receuire il purrount
Cil ki ben entendrount

msItem.author: Adam de Ross
msItem.incipit:
228r Seignurs freres or escotez
Vus ki estes a deu nomez
Aidez mai a translater
La visiun sein pol le ber
Dampne deu par sa dousur
E par la sue grant amur
Out merci e memorie
Del almes ki furent en purgatorie
msItem.explicit:
230v Sein michel li ad ceo dit
Ami kar deu aueient en despit
Lur chastete vnc ne garderent
Ne dampne deu plein iur ne amerent Vnc ne chiurent parent

handDesc.handNote: Folios 125r-127r ln. 15 written in a neat textualis by CCCC MS 405 'Scribe 2' who also seems to be responsible for the text on ff. 8v-10r and ff. 231r-245r. 'Scribe 2' writes a prose introduction in Latin to the Anglo-Norman poetry that follows in the hand of 'Scribe 1'.

handNote.p: Folios 127r ln 16 written by CCCC MS 405 'Scribe 1', the scribe of ff. 3v-5v and 43r-92r. 'Scribe 1' copies the Anglo-Norman poetry that follows a prose introduction in Latin written by 'Scribe 2'

Plain initial 'B' in a 'Lombardic' style in red on f. 125r, and at the start of each new poem after the first.
Initials at the beginning of sentences and minor divisions of the text touched with red througout the Part.

msItem.author: Edward III, King of England
msItem.incipit: 250r Edwardus dei gratia etcetera Omnibus ad quos presentes litere peruenerint salutem
msItem.explicit: 250r Teste me ipso apud Westminster .xvmo. die . Ianuarii . Anno regis nostri quarto . per peticionem de consilio

msItem.title: Grant to Johannis de ?Calwodeleye by Prior Walter and the Knights Hospitallers of Ireland
msItem.incipit: 250v Vniuersis sancte matris ecclesie filiis ad quos presens scriptum peruenerit ffrater walterus de Emirus prior fratrum hospitalis Ierusalem in hibernia salutem . Nouerit vniuersitas vestra nos de communi consilio fratrum tocius caputili nostri in hibernia concessisse et hac presenti carta nostra confirmasse Iohanni de Calwodeleye totam terram nostram de Dromconan.
msItem.explicit: 250v in festo sancti micheli hiis testibus fratre laurentius . fratre stephano capellanis . fratre dauid de castellis . fratre nicholo de maincestre . fratre walter de lyndisheye . fratre rogero clerio . fratre Adem de sandime . et aliis

note.p: The grant is undated. It is possible that the 'Walter de Emirus' mentioned in the text may be the former prior of the Hospitallers in Kilmainham, Dublin, better known as Walter de Aqua / Walter Dewyas / Walter de Ewyas. The Registrum de Kilmainham (now Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Rawlinson B 501 ) contains a copy of a grant on ff. 61rv of a 'Frater Walterus de Ewyas' who seems to have been Grand Prior of the hospitallers in Ireland for an unknown duration during the first quarter of the 14th century. The grant in MS Rawlinson B 501 has a witness list which includes some of the same people who witnessed the grant in CCCC MS 405 including 'fratre Laurencio ... fratre Dauid de Castello ... fratre Waltero de Lindeseya, fratre Rogero clerico, fratre Ada de Suandime ...'.
The land referred to in the grant, 'Dromconan', probably refers to Drom ConÃ¡in / Drumcannon in County Waterford, Ireland.

note.p:
Full transcription:
O preclarum mundi iubar stella vespertina predicator uoto martyr te decet laus bina per te nostra restauretur antoni ruina ... â Et lingua eius etc .
Ecclesiam tuam deus beati antonii confessoris tui commemorem uotiua letificet ut spiritualibus semper muniatur auxiliis et gaudiis perfrui mereatur eternis Per christum dominum nostrum AMEN
Text unclear due to abrasion of the leaf.

collation.p: Quire 23five (ff. 247-251; original quire structure undertermined, five leaves remain)

signatures.p: No leaf signatures particular to this Part.
No quire signatures particular to this Part.

catchwords.seg: No catchwords particular to this Part.

supportDesc.condition: In fair condition. The bottom quarter of folio 250 has been trimmed away with no obvious loss of text. Folio 251 (in particular the verso) is badly rubbed, perhaps due to former use as a pastedown, and some of the text is now very difficult to read.

p.seg: Folios 247v-250r ruled in light brown ink, frame and lines. Ruled in single-column format, typically 26 lines to the page, fewer lines on f. 250 due to trimming of the leaf. Folio 250v informally written.

layout.seg: Folio 251r ruled in leadpoint, frame and lines. Ruled in single-column format, frame and lines, 34 lines to the page.

p.seg: Folio 251v: no ruling visible due to damage to leaf. Two formal scribal stints by different scribes, 20 lines above, 6 lines below.

handNote.p: Folios 247v-250v written in a chancery hand in an 'anglicana' style.

handDesc.handNote: Folio 251 written in northern textualis libraria by three different scribes.

decoNote.p: Large plain initial 'I' in red on f. 251v.

note.p: Folio 247r: A note in ink in a medieval hand, 'pro effus sanguinis item'.

binding.p: Folio 251 perhaps used as a pastedown in a former binding as their is adhesive residue and significant loss of text due to rubbing (or peeling) on the verso.

origin.p: Date and place of production assigned based on palaeographical features. The Letters Patent of King Edward III on ff. 247v-248v are dated to the fifth year of Edward's reign (i.e., 1332/1333), so the copy must have been made after that date.
